children.subject: i heard it's somewhat useful to crytography?

I haven't taken any cryptography, but after looking at the CS 276 website, I think you would be fine with the introductory number theory you learn in a CS 70 type of class. It seems like in research-level cryptography there is some connection to elliptic curves, but I don't think 113 would cover these. It does seem like if you are doing cryptography research, then it could potentially be helpful to learn a lot of algebra. I think the best idea would be to take some classes (e.g. 276 next year) to see if you like cryptography before learning math that is not going to be useful in other applications. If you are a math/CS double then maybe try taking both and see if you can handle it. I think 113 covers groups, rings, and fields at an introductory level, so it theoretically shouldn't be that bad if you have previous experience with math. Which other math classes have you taken?
I'm not doubling with math, so 113 would be the first upper math class I take, since this is mentioned, is doubling math/cs worth it if I'm interested in theory?

113 is probably fine as a first upper div, though it might be harder for you than I initially suggested. I don't think a double would be incredibly useful unless you want to go to grad school for CS theory. I think if you wanted to go to grad school, it could be useful to know basic algebra and analysis, but even then, you could probably just take these classes in grad school or learn them on your own. As a math/CS major intending to go to math grad school, I have noticed very little overlap in my classes, aside from linear algebra, which is used in basically every math class and some CS classes. Having some analysis knowledge was kind of helpful in CS 270, but I think you could get similar intuition from taking a class like 126, which is definitely more helpful in CS as a whole.

I'm a math/cs double major and I've taken both Math 113 and CS61C. If you're interested in exploring mathematics, then math 113 would be one of my top recommendations. In my opinion it was the most interesting of the upper division math "core courses" (110,113,104,185). It's also very useful for understanding public-key cryptography. If that kind of this sounds interesting to you I would also strongly recommend Math 116 (cryptography) in the fall with Prof Dorfsman-Hopkins. He's my favorite math professor (I also took 113 with him). I took his crypto course in the Fall and it was bar none the most fun and rewarding math course I've taken at Berkeley. It was medium-light in difficulty and is a mixture of theory with (relatively simple) programming assignments (implementing RSA and elliptic curve cryptosystems and more). His course builds from the ground up so you don't need math 113 before hand, but you'd attain greater insights if you did.

As for CS61C that class is brutal during a normal length semester. Not super difficult material, but a very intense workload.
Idk about the first two questions, but the algebra you would probably learn in 113 has not been useful to me in any CS theory classes. I haven't taken 61C yet though, so I can't comment on that
How is 61C related to graphics? I don't think graphics showed up in that class.

I'm no expert but a large part of graphics is getting things to run fast, and 61C is partially an intro to performance computing. There's also a short dive into GPUs in the course, and you learn about what makes different computer architectures different. I would consider 61C a prereq to 184 as well.

If you're interested in graphics, then 61c is for sure more useful. It's often taught by Dan Garcia who specializes in graphics and he loves to bring up connections between low level computing and graphics. CS 184 is our graphics class and is taught in C++, so you will also want a grasp on the C language before taking that. As others stated, 113 can help with some CS theory (I for sure understand some parts of 70 much better now), but 61c exposes you to at least finite state machines, logic, and computation, which all have rich theory.

history.content: Impossible to take both. Take CS 184 if you are interested in computer graphics, which requires programming in C (taught in CS 61C). Here is the CS 184 syllabus: https://tbp.berkeley.edu/syllabi/998/download/

children.subject: Just some context, 61c had weeks where it took as much or more time than CS70 for me. This is around 25-30 hours on a project week, I took ~40 hours on a project week but I was in OH a lot.

history.content:
approximately how many hours do I need to work per week for that schedule? 

If it's impossible, and I'm more interested in graphics(or cs theory in general), which one is more recommended to take earlier? Thanks!
